DataElement.preferredName: Surgical Margin Neoplasm Distance Unit of Measure
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Standard unit of measure applied to the distance from a neoplasm to a surgical margin.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The space between two objects or points.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Property.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:The space between two objects or points.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The space separating two objects or points.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8/7/17 tt transferred context and added registration status, CSI per Round 5 finalization task.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A named quantity in terms of which other quantities are measured or specified, used as a standard measurement of like kinds.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

Concepts.definition: A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

Concepts.definition: A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A traditional unit of length defined by the U.S. National Bureau of Standards as 30.48 centimeters. It is equal to 0.3048 meter, 12 inches, or to approximately 0.999998 survey foot.

Concepts.definition: A traditional unit of length defined by the U.S. National Bureau of Standards as 30.48 centimeters. It is equal to 0.3048 meter, 12 inches, or to approximately 0.999998 survey foot.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The unit of linear measure in the metric system, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). Meter is defined as the length of the path traveled by light in a vacuum during a time interval of 1/299 792 458 of a second and is equal to 1.093 61 yards.

Concepts.definition: A unit of linear measure in the metric system, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). A meter is defined as the length of the path traveled by light in a vacuum during a time interval of 1/299 792 458 of a second and is equal to 1.093 61 yards.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the units of measure for assessment results and dosing.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A named quantity in terms of which other quantities are measured or specified used as a standard measurement of same kinds, such as pound or kilogram in measuring weight. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: A named quantity in terms of which other quantities are measured or specified, used as a standard measurement of like kinds.
